Summary:

A collection of snippets depicting the friendship between the God of Geo and the God of Dust.

"Wisdom is like water, it nourishes all those who receive it and in it is a reflection of the truth."'

ğŸ¥€ğŸ¥€ğŸ¥€

I first saw you in a field of flowers.

The ringing in my ears that day wouldnâ€™t stop. If I had known it was a premonition, then I wouldnâ€™t have approached you the way I didâ€” or maybe it would have been better if I hadnâ€™t altogether.
 
The sky that day was a beautiful hue of orange, but if one squints hard enough, then I dare say the color resembled your hair. 

ğŸ¥€ğŸ¥€ğŸ¥€

The cool afternoon breeze danced around the lone feminine figure as she walked along the edges of Dihua Marsh. The breeze played with her flowing robes and hair, whimsically picking it up and down, to and froâ€” as if it had a mind of its own. 

Humming to herself in content, she bent down to pluck a glaze lily, her most favorite flower. As her hands gracefully bring the flower up, her head bends slightly down, intending to meet the flower halfway. 

But the blue flowerâ€™s fragrance never got to reach her nose.

â€œHaaa.â€ A sigh.

Her head jolted to the source of the sound, the motion ruining her once elegant demeanor. 

In place of the sound stood a tall, young(?) man. His long, black, flowing hair, rivaling hers in length, was kept in a low ponytail. His black robes were as elegant and frivolous as hers, indicating that he was not a mere villager.

As if on cue with their eye contact, the breeze started to pick up, causing the lone petals on the ground to scatter up and about. As the two internally battled to keep eye contact, the blue petals slowly descended back to the ground, losing their battle to gravity. 

It was a picturesque-perfect sceneâ€” maybe the breeze did have a mind of its own. 

â€œD-Did you just sigh at me?â€ the female asked, looking perplexed at the man standing a few feet from her.

â€œHmm, Iâ€™m not so sure myself. Did I?â€ the man responded, lowering his gaze to the flower in her hand.

His shift in attention hadnâ€™t gone unnoticed.

â€œAh, are you perhaps inquiring about this?â€ she motioned to the flower, slowly twirling it counterclockwise.

He gave a small nod in response.

â€œItâ€™s a glaze lily. Iâ€™m very fond of them,â€ she continued, this time giving it a small whiff to make up for the missed opportunity from before. â€œTheyâ€™re beautiful, donâ€™t you think?â€

She looked up. 

No response.

He stared intently at her, â€œif you are as fond of it as you say you are, then why did you cut its life short?â€

Her eyes widened in shock, visibly taken aback by his rather direct question.

Delicate fingers found its way to her chin as she pondered, looking for a satisfactory enough answer. 

â€œWellâ€¦,â€ she started looking down, long lashes clouding her eyes.

â€œIf you truly hold someone close to your heart, then wouldnâ€™t you want them with you?â€ she looked up, meeting his gaze, lashes raised to unveil the many layers of depth.

Brown meets amber in an abyss of loud silence.

â€œEhâ€” of course Iâ€™m not saying you should kill off people you hold dear butâ€”,â€ confidence parted with her as quickly as it had come.

â€œYou see, itâ€™s different when itâ€™s a flower. Plucking it from its roots doesnâ€™t mean inevitable death. If I care for it well then itâ€™ll continue to blossom.â€

â€œNonetheless, regardless of whether one harbors human emotions or not, it is ultimately best to let it be,â€ the man shot back.

â€œPardon? Human emotions?â€ 

â€œYes, human emotions. It is because of said emotions that humans are rendered as weak as they are. They are nothing but a handicap and is the reason why humans depend on us gods.â€

â€œUs? Gods?â€ she questioned flabbergasted.

The man held his sternness, unfazed by his counterpart choking on her words.

â€œAhâ€¦ So you know,â€ Guizhong sighed as she parted her bangs from her forehead,

â€œIâ€™m Guizhong. God of Dust,â€ she extended her hand, shortening the distance between them. 

â€œMorax. Morax, God of Geo.â€

Guizhongâ€™s extended arm was left unattended as Morax turned away from her and started his trek away. 


She looked up at him perplexed and stared daggers into his retreating back. But despite the look she gave him, she decided it would be a good idea to finish the rest of her stroll besides him. After all, it wasnâ€™t everyday you find a fellow god on human lands, much less when and where the glaze lilies were blooming. 

This was definitely a sign. 

She grabbed parts of her robes and pulled them up lightly, ensuring she wasnâ€™t harming them anywhere, and jogged up to him. 

Upon her appearance at his side, he eyed her, raising his left eyebrow, giving her a most suspicious look. A look Guizhong ignored. 

â€œSoâ€¦â€ she started, trying to ease the tension. â€œWhat are you doing on mortal lands?â€

â€œNothing.â€

â€œAwe, come on, there must be a reason as to why youâ€™re down here,â€ she whined at his lame answer. â€œIâ€™ve been down here many, many, times and not once have I encountered another deity.â€

â€œHmph,â€ he glanced at her, keeping his head forward. â€œEven if I did have a reason, I do not have a reason to share it with you.â€

â€œFine, alright.â€ she lowered her head defeatedly. â€œSorry I cared and asked.â€

Moraxâ€™s attention is now fully on the road they were walking whilst Guizhongâ€™s was at the ground beneath her and the flower in her hand.

The awkwardness was killing her. She didnâ€™t know how to keep a conversation with someone as boring and dull as Morax.

Why did she even decide to join him in the first place? She racked her brain over and over at the rash decision to run up to and walk alongside him. 

â€œIt would be best if you stopped wearing your heart on your sleeve.â€

As luck would have it, she did not need to break the silence.

â€œAnd whatâ€™s the matter with that?â€ she inquired looking up from the ground, fixing her posture at the same time.

â€œEverything. Maybe coming down here so often negatively impacted you,â€ Morax continued. â€œAlas, there must be a reason as to why you donâ€™t see anyone else.â€

â€œYou do know that â€˜everythingâ€™ doesnâ€™t answer anything, right?â€ she remarked, slowly losing her patience.

Haa. Another sigh elicited from the tall man. 

â€œHarboring human emotions will do you no benefit. Nor coming all the way here, unless there is a good enough reason,â€ he explained.

She eyed him victoriously. â€œSo you do have a reason.â€

Morax guffawed at her ignoring his main point altogether. â€œThat was not my point.â€

â€œYeah yeah,â€ she smiled, turning back to the road, happy to have dodged his judgemental comment with her sly one. 

They once again fell into silence. However, Guizhong thought it wasnâ€™t so awkward this time. After all, it is only awkward if she makes it awkward.

Nonetheless, she decided to speak up again, â€œSo Morax, tell me about yourself.â€

To her sudden inquiry, he turned to her hesitantly. Upon looking at her face, he was greeted with a solemn, yet sincere, smile. One that showed her eagerness to hearing his story, no traces of a possible rejection in it. 

Drawn to the serenity, he couldnâ€™t help but open his mouth. 

~~~~~

She had listen to him intently, making sure to not miss a single word from the Geo Archon.

As his story was coming to a close, so did their stroll together.

â€œSay, since I have done all the talking, it is your turn.â€

Guizhong chuckled. â€œMust I have to? Our journey together is nearing its end,â€ she said as she looked down the road before them.
Morax followed the direction of her gaze.

â€œNot quite yet. There is still a good amount of steps left.â€

She hummed in agreement, â€œwell what would you like to inquire about?â€

He looked at her, then at the flower still snuggled in her hand.

â€œThe glaze lily, why are you so fond of them? They are most obviously the reason as to why you are down here, on this day and time.â€

As the steps required to finish the path they were on lowered, Guizhong thought deep and hard at Moraxâ€™s question. 

â€œThere is no particular reason as to why I am this fond of them,â€ she smiled looking down at the flower and giving it a subtle twirl.

â€œBut if I were to give a reason, then it would be because it reminds me of humans,â€ she looked up to meet his gaze.

At where they are, they can see the city coming into view, their journey together coming ever so closer to an end. 

His gaze darkened at her naivety, most fondness he had found for her beginning to fade. 

â€œYou must think Iâ€™m stupid for sympathizing with them,â€ she started.

"But those humans are as small and fragile as dust,â€ she continued. "And because they are so small, they know not when they will lose their lives to disaster or strife, and so they are afraid."

"And because they are afraid, they try harder to become more intelligent. In a sense, they are like glaze lilies, fighting for survival amongst a cruel world," she said as her gaze shifted from flower to the city before them. 

Then she turned back to him. â€œYou had asked me why I come down here as often as I do. It is because I want to help those humans. The same ones you presume are weak.â€

"And I thought that since there is such a gulf between us in strength, I should use technique and wisdom instead. With your brawn and my brains, Iâ€™m sure this city would surely become a great one,â€œ she finished in a hush and faced him with her most lovely, yet lonely, smile. 

Moraxâ€™s expression darkened. 

â€œGuizhong. You know I can not.â€
She looked down and nodded solemnly.

â€œIt was at least worth a shot,â€ she hummed. â€œFor I can not achieve this alone.â€

He sympathetically looked at her, then to the flower in her hand, then to the village just across the shore from them.

He sighed in defeat.

â€œIâ€¦â€ he started. â€œI can assist you.â€

Her head jolted, revealing her surprised expression at his sudden change in decision.
 
â€œO-Only if you prove to me they are worthy of the Geo Archonâ€™s help.â€

Guizhong was beaming at his earlier statement, his new one doing little to change her giddiness.

â€œYes, I shall prove to you what they are capable of,â€ she said excitedly as she took his hands in hers, squishing the flower between their palms.

Morax nodded, expressing his â€˜youâ€™re welcome.â€™

â€œItâ€™s a contract then,â€ she beamed remembering his fondness of contracts when he told her about himself.

Morax flashed a light grin, â€œIndeed. Indeed it is.â€

â€œOh, here!â€ her eyes turned wide as she fumbled in her pockets and pulled out a stone dumbbell. â€œTake this!â€

She ushered Morax to open his hand so she could hand him said â€˜stone dumbbellâ€™.

â€œThis is the mark of our pledge, and it is also my challenge to you.â€

Morax looked at her in a most confused look, â€œChallenge?â€

â€œAll my wisdom is hidden within this stone dumbbell,â€ she answered. â€œIn exchange for helping me, you will acquire my wisdom.â€ 

â€œThat isâ€¦ only if you are able to unlock it,â€ she smiled cheekily, glancing from him to the dumbbell, now in his hands. 

â€œHow is this a fair deal?â€ he asked her amused, raising his left eyebrow.
 â€œIf your brain holds intellect, you should be able to open it. And if you do, then I would be at the lower end of the deal. Itâ€™s more than fair, no?â€

Morax did not have anything to say, so Guizhong took his silence as agreement to their contract.

â€œWell, this journey has come to an end,â€ Guizhong said as she looked over the marsh, night falling over them.

Mhm. Morax hummed in agreement.

â€œBut it wonâ€™t be our last one together,â€ she smiled as she looked back at him.

Mhm. Morax hummed again in agreement.

On that day and at that place, when and where the glaze lilies were in abundant bloom, was also the day my life was permanently altered. 

I think glaze lilies have also become something I am very fond of. 

A lot of what you like has grown on me, not because of the reasons you like them for though, but because they all remind me of you. 

Every time that fateful season comes around, when they are at their peak, I canâ€™t help but find my way back to Dihua Marsh. 

Most of me wants to move on and leave you behind, but a part of me wants to be taken back to that time and place.

Back to when I saw you in a field of flowers.

"Virtue grows tall like a tree, though there be shade it will flourish forever."

ğŸ¥€ğŸ¥€ğŸ¥€

The second time I saw you was not as memorable as the first, but little did I know that that day would be one of the few I cherish. 

Even after all these years, the memories have not left me, and I doubt it ever will. 

Every so often, I canâ€™t help but reminisce back to then.

Morax squinted as remnants of the sun fought through the cracks and openings of the very same item Guizhong had entrusted him with. 

In the few days following his meeting with the God of Dust, he spent his waking hours trying to figure out the stone dumbbell and retrieve â€˜Guizhongâ€™s wisdomâ€™ as she had promised.

Being on the losing end of a contract did not sit well with the God of Contracts himself. 

As one hand lifted up the item in question to the light, his other hand sat on the round stone tabletop, fingers tapping away in a synchronized rhythm. 

How pointless. Morax thought to himself as his fingers rotated the stone dumbbell, also dubbed â€˜puzzleâ€™ by Guizhong herself. 

He did not go through the trouble of counting but it mustâ€™ve been on the 100th rotation when he heard an all too familiar voice behind him. 

â€œMorâ€” uh Zhongli!â€ a feminine voice called out to the waiting adepti.

Morax had given Guizhong the name â€˜Zhongliâ€™, to be used when they were on mortal lands. While doing so, he attempted to settle on one for Guizhong herself. But to his suggestion, she told him that it was already too late for her to be using an alias. A fact he deadpanned at. 

â€œZhongli!â€ Guizhong called again as the distance between them closed. â€œMy apologies, did you wait for long?â€

To her inquiry, the sitting adepti looked up at her. He showed her the puzzle, nestled between his thumb and his index fingers, giving it a little shake. 

â€œNo, it wasnâ€™t that long a wait,â€ he started. â€œBut any second tardier, and I would have decided to smash this dumbbell into the stone table.â€

Guizhong rolled her eyes at her partnerâ€™s remark.

â€œSurely that would â€˜solveâ€™ it,â€ she decided to play along with him, her fingers forming makeshift quotation marks to put emphasis on â€˜solveâ€™. 

Zhongli nodded slightly from where he sat. â€œI am the brawns after all.â€

His reference to their conversation a few days back stifled a light chuckle from Guizhong.

â€œAlright alright, you win,â€ she said as she sat down on the stone stool just on the other side of him.

She shuffled around a bit on the stool before settling into a comfy enough position, both hands on the table in an upright stance to support her chin, and ultimately, her upper body, slightly leaning over the table. 

Zhongli noted her posture could be better but decided against verbalizing his inner monologue. 

â€œSo how are you faring out with the puzzle?â€ Guizhong asked, eyeing her possession in his hands.

He shrugged. â€œIâ€™m convinced you had done something to rig it.â€

His suspicion uttered a loud laugh from Guizhong. Her back contorted backwards, further terrorizing her already questionable posture, as her hands reached for her stomach, any elegance she had left trailing away from her. 

â€œNo, no I do not think I did,â€ she started as her chimes died down. 

Zhongli looked down at the puzzle still perched in his hand, patiently waiting to be solved.

â€œWell, progress could be better.â€

Guizhong left his response unattended as she, too, looked down at the stone dumbbell in his hands, boredly eyeing it. 

â€œEnough with trying to figure it out,â€ she whined as she stood up from her stool, long hair draping over her shoulders. â€œHow about we get this day started and do what we had come to accomplish?â€

The feminine figure extended her hands towards Zhongli, who was still sitting, dumbbell in his hands.

He looked up at her and smiled, tucking the dumbbell away back into the confines of his dark robes, in contrast from Guizhongâ€™s light ones.

Despite his shift in attitude compared to their first encounter, he left her hand hanging, as with the first time. But he nevertheless took the spot beside her as they walked away from the set of table and stools on the side of the road.

~~~

â€œHow are you planning to accomplish your goal today?â€ Zhongli inquired as the sunâ€™s rays got all the more impenetrable, the effects of summer getting more and more obvious to him on mortal lands.

Guizhong beamed at his question. Her hands found their way to pockets hidden inside the many layers of her robe, fumbling around for something.

â€œAh!â€ she made a sound of affirmation, moving her hands around, seemingly to confirm the item she found was indeed the right one.

â€œHere!â€ she said as she whipped the item out, her speed making Zhongli jump in surprise.

She held the parchment scroll horizontally, letting gravity do its job as the content unfolded itself. The extended scrollâ€™s length reached past her waist from her chin.

Both adeptis halted in their tracks, Guizhong excitedly showing off her pride, Zhongli looking at her quizzically, convinced sheâ€™s not as intelligent as they both thought she was.

â€œThis is a list of what we are gonna do today!â€

â€œYou want us toâ€¦ to do all of that?â€ Zhongli asked as he grimaced at the numerous lines stacked on top of each other. It seemed Guizhong had utilized the parchmentâ€™s full length.

â€œWell I had a hard time fishing out the humanâ€™s best qualities, so I wrote out all of them,â€ Guizhong started as she angled the front of the parchment towards her so she could look over its contents.

â€œAlthough it does look like a whole lot...â€ she sighed as she stared at the parchment from top to bottom. 

Her delicate fingers found its way to her chin, a gesture she often does when she is in deep thought, Zhongli noted.

â€œI guess Iâ€™ll just have to choose the best options from this extensive list,â€ she reasoned.

â€œThat is indeed quite the extensive list,â€ he looked at her then to the sun, now directly above them, signalling high noon.

â€œThe day is halfway over,â€ his gaze found his way back to her. â€œAre you sure you can convince me?â€

In response to his challenge, she grinned and rolled the scroll back up.

â€œEven if I did not have this,â€ with the scroll now rolled back up to its original shape and in her hand, she elegantly tapped his nose with it, â€œI think I will fare just fine.â€

Now back on the dirt road, Guizhong started walking ahead, slightly faster than before to make up for their wasted time.

She turned back to the male figure, â€œUnlike you with the stone dumbbell.â€

At the remark, Zhongli chuckled and walked to catch up to her, not finding the need to jog as his human legs were a whole few inches taller than hers.

~~~

Laughter and chatter danced their way around the adepti pair as they entered the human city.

To Zhongliâ€™s left, were local street vendors selling their specialties, bellowing over their stands hoping to attract attention and share their gift to the rest of the world. To his right were like minded shoppers, walking up and down the marketplace, inspecting the goods, wisely choosing what to spend their money onâ€” as they did not have much to begin with.

â€œWelcome to the city!â€ Guizhong chirped, as she walked in front of Zhongli, with her back facing the front. â€œThis is where weâ€™ll be spending the rest of our day.â€

It would be an understatement to say that her walking backwards made him nervous. 

â€œDoes this city not have a name?â€ Zhongli inquired, noting what Guizhong had called the city.

â€œMmm, no,â€ she started. â€œNot yet at least. It seems the residents have yet to come up with one.â€ 

By now, she had resumed the normal way of walking, melting into her place besides Zhongli once again. 

â€œYou see, it has just been recently established.â€

Not seeing the need to verbally respond, he nodded softly, signalling his understanding to Guizhong. 

His passiveness,however, did not faze his female companion as she smirked at him, â€œwho knows, maybe you can name it.â€

â€œI highly doubt the chances of that.â€

Ignoring Zhongliâ€™s pessimism, she shrugged. â€œYou can never be too sure.â€

Just as she had finished her sentence, a voice chimed in from the duoâ€™s left.

â€œGuizhong!â€ a booming voice beckoned. â€œJust how long has it been?â€ 

Both adeptis halted in their tracks, heads turning to their left to the source of the new voice.

The man who called for Guizhong seemed to be in his late 20s. His hair was a light fluffy brown, bangs messy but the rest of its length was tied into a bun, the green ribbon flowing down behind him. He wore a simple green colored garment, which further accentuated his fondness for the color.

Zhongli eyed Guizhong questioningly. Guizhong, oblivious to Zhongliâ€™s silent inquiry, half-skipped her way to the stand and to the man awaiting her just on the other side of it.

â€œAh! Guan Suo!â€ Guizhong beamed at the man in question. â€œHas it been that long? I remember it only being a week or two.â€ 

Zhongli hesitantly followed Guizhong, halting in his tracks just beside her. The stand was small in width, but long in length. Zhongli noticed that it was home to many different types of pottery, its many many hues of colors, shapes, and sizes clashing with each other. However, when all put together, the visual presentation was nonetheless stunning. He wouldnâ€™t be surprised if the stand alone attracted a good amount of curious onlookers. It was the only color in the otherwise dull, wooden building behind the seller. 

â€œWell, it felt wayyy longer than that for me,â€ Guan Suo responded, seemingly ecstatic at Guizhongâ€™s unexpected drop-by, completely ignoring Zhongli. 

Ahem. 

Both heads turned to Zhongli, the source of the sound.

Guizhong sent him a quick glare, seemingly upset at his rude way of interrupting her â€˜catching upâ€™ session.

â€œThis is my good friend Zhongli,â€ she nevertheless introduced him to the man over the stand. â€œZhongli, this is my other good friend, Guan Suo.â€ 

â€œAh! How nice to meet you!â€ Guan Suo started, extending a hand towards Zhongli. 

Zhongli stared at it until he felt a nudge at his side. It was Guizhong ushering him to not leave the poor man hanging.

â€œLikewise,â€ he took it and gave Guan Suo a firm, solid shake, although begrudgingly. 

To this, Guan Suo shrugged and continued his earlier conversation with Guizhong. 

â€œHow long will you be here for? Are you free later? We could grab something to eat and catch up.â€ 

Guizhong looked at him apprehensively, â€œAh, apologies Guan Suo. I have something to attend to for the rest of the day today.â€

â€œOh, thatâ€™s fine too!â€ he responded happily, although the disappointment was clear.

â€œMaybe next time?â€ 

â€œYeah, for sure! Just tell me when youâ€™re here and Iâ€™ll close up shop early just for you mâ€™lady.â€

Zhongli noticed Guizhongâ€™s cheeks were now a slightly pinker shade than before.

Guizhong nodded happily at Guan Suoâ€™s suggestion.

Zhongli scoffed at the interaction. â€œAre you done now Guizhong? We must get going if you wish to finish the rest of your list.â€

She looked up at him, nodding in agreement. â€œAh youâ€™re right, we shall go.â€

â€œIâ€™ll see you next time Guan Suo,â€ she waved at the man before turning to catch up to Zhongli who had already started the trek away. 

â€œLikewise,â€ the man over the stand waved, as he looked at the two retreating backs.

~~~ 

â€œZhongli wait up!â€ Guizhong called as she struggled to catch up to him. â€œMust you be in such a hurry?â€

â€œI am just attempting to finish your list in time,â€ he responded, slowing down a bit for her.

â€œWell, one item on my list was to introduce you to all my friends here,â€ she said between breaths as she finally caught up to him.

Zhongliâ€™s eyes narrowed. â€œYou best think of a new one to replace that item or omit it altogether if that is the case.â€

â€œHm? How come?â€ she looked up at him from her spot besides him as they continued to walk through the marketplace.

â€œAlternatively, you can keep it and fail to convince me,â€ he suggested. â€œSo far, your list is failing to do so.â€

Guizhong sighed. â€œAlright. I understand that you have trouble interacting with mere humans. Thanks Grandpa, Iâ€™ll keep that in mind. â€

Zhongli ignored her.

â€œAnyways, the location for one of my other items is just ahead of us!â€ Guizhong pointed to a stand a few feet away from them.

â€œI hope youâ€™re hungry cause itâ€™s time for lunch,â€ grabbing Zhongliâ€™s arm, she dragged him to the place in question. 

â€œOur kind do not starve,â€ Zhongli told her as he was being dragged after her. 

â€œWhatever, grandpa,â€ she rolled her eyes. â€œAt least weâ€™re not impartial to taste.â€ 

â€œGuizhong! Pleasure seeing you here!â€ a high, elated voice sounded from behind the stand.

The greeting belonged to a young female. Under the sun, her hair shined a light brown, almost sandy. Her light bangs, with two longer strands on either side of her face, framed her small face, giving her an even more youthful look. The rest of her hair was held in a low braided bun, crowned with a green embroidered headpiece, with the rest of her attire being a light, almost pastel, blue. 

â€œBao!â€ Guizhong chimed, lifting her right hand to wave at the girl behind the stand.

Her left hand pulled at Zhongliâ€™s sleeves, bringing him  closer to her, until they were only a few inches apart.

â€œThis is Zhongli, a good friend of mine.â€

Bao directed her gaze to her friendâ€™s left and eyed the man in question up and down.

â€œO-Oh my Guizhong,â€ Baoâ€™s gaze stopped at the male adeptiâ€™s face. â€œYou didnâ€™t tell me you were friends with someone as attractive as him.â€

Guizhong snorted at her friendâ€™s remark, knowing that adeptis can choose any form they wish to inhabit. 

â€œWell I had just met him,â€ Guizhong shrugged.

â€œAh!â€ Baoâ€™s eyes widened as she remembered something. â€œIâ€™m Bao by the way. Bao Sanniang.â€

The girl waved to Zhongli from behind the food stand.

â€œPleasure to meet you,â€ Zhongli responded, giving her a small smile, resulting in the femaleâ€™s now reddened cheeks.

â€œS-So Guizhong, would you like the usual?â€ deciding the manâ€™s attention was too much for her, Bao turned hers back to her friend. 

â€œYes please, but add just one more,â€ Guizhong said, eyeing Zhongli. 

â€œGot it,â€ Bao responded happily as she bent down to grab something from the stallâ€™s confines, starting Guizhongâ€™s orders.

â€œSo,â€ Guizhong turned to her partner for the day. â€œDo you have some mora prepared?â€

â€œPardon?â€ Zhongli turned his attention down to her as the two waited for Bao in front of the stand.

â€œMora.â€ 

â€œWhat?â€

â€œMora. Itâ€™s only the currency the whole of Teyvat uses.â€

â€œI know what it is,â€ Zhongli deadpanned. â€œIt was named after me,â€ he whispered the latter, rather aggressively. 

Guizhongâ€™s eyes slightly widened at the newfound knowledge, lips parting to form a silent â€˜oâ€™ upon drawing the connection.

â€œThen what on Teyvat are you asking for?â€

â€œWell, I donâ€™t have any on me,â€ he passively responded. 

â€œAh...,â€ Guizhong was quick to catch on. â€œItâ€™s still quite a shame,â€ she giggled at the irony. 

â€œIâ€™ve never had the need for such trivial things,â€ he said, indirectly hinting at the other part of Liyue, the one which mortals are not as familiar with.

â€œWell, itâ€™s alright,â€ Guizhong smiled at him, reaching inside her robe. â€œIt is my honor to pay for you.â€
